Multiple imputations by two-level model

Source: vignettes/articles/Two-level-mi.Rmd
Two-level-mi.Rmd

\newcommand{\TPi}{\mbox{TP}_i} \newcommand{\FNi}{\mbox{FN}_i} \newcommand{\FPi}{\mbox{FP}_i} \newcommand{\TNi}{\mbox{TN}_i} \newcommand{\logit}{{\rm logit}}

Set-up and notation

Suppose there are mm studies to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of some test. For the iith study, let

  • $\TPi$: number of true positives
  • $\FNi$: number of false negatives
  • $\FPi$: number of false positives
  • $\TNi$: number of true negatives

These are the data we wish to collect for each i=1,‚Ä¶,mi=1,\ldots, m. Write $N_i=\TPi+\FNi$, the number of cases; $\bar N_i=\FPi + \TNi$, the number of non-cases; and ni=Ni+N‚Äæin_i = N_i + \bar N_i, the total sample size.

Let pip_i denote the sensitivity, qiq_i the specificity, and œÄi\pi_i the prevalence of cases in the iith study. If there is no missing data, we can easily estimate them by $\hat p_i=\TPi/N_i$, $\hat q_i=\TNi/\bar N_i$, and œÄÃÇi=Ni/ni\hat\pi_i=N_i/n_i, respectively. We can also feed the entire data $(\TPi, \FNi, \FPi, \TNi)$ (i=1,‚Ä¶,m)(i=1,\ldots, m) into any standard software, e.g., mada (Sousa-Pinto 2022), for meta-analysis.

Methods

A motivating example

Consider the scenario where there are no non-cases in some study ii, so $\FNi$, $\TNi=$NA. An example:

library(mtroc)
uts
#>            TP FN FP  TN
#> Ahn        19  0 NA  NA
#> Bock        5  5  2  17
#> Chung       5  0 48 114
#> Cordoba    21  1 NA  NA
#> Espinosa    5  0 NA  NA
#> Haliloglu   3  0  1  73
#> Langer     57 17 NA  NA
#> Liberman    6  0 NA  NA
#> Nishanova  26  4 NA  NA
#> Obenauer    2  2  0  23
#> Oh          9  0 NA  NA
#> Qian       50  1 63  92
#> Reyes      32  1 NA  NA
#> Robbins     4  0 17 101
#> Taskin     47  0 NA  NA
#> Taylor     21  0 NA  NA
#> Yang       21  0 NA  NA
#> Myers      33  0 NA  NA
#> Taron      19  0 NA  NA
#> Son         6  0  6  23
#> Jafari     31  0 NA  NA
#> Wang      110 18 NA  NA

We aim to fill in the missing values of $\FNi$ and $\TNi$ by multiple imputations (MI).

Two-level random-effects models

We can think of the data as generated in two stages. First, with total sample size nin_i, the relative size of NiN_i vs N‚Äæi\bar N_i is determined by prevalence œÄi\pi_i. Second, given NiN_i and N‚Äæi\bar N_i, the relative size of $\TPi$ vs $\FNi$, and that of $\FPi$ vs $\TNi$, are determined by sensitivity pip_i and specificity qiq_i, respectively. This leads us to posit a two-level model for prevalence and for sensitivity-specificity relationship: the first allows us to impute the size of cases or non-cases; the second to impute specificity from sensitivity (or vice versa).

To account for between-study heterogeneity, we add study-specific random effects on the logit scale of each model. Write ${\rm logit}(x)=\log\{x/(1-x)\}$. $$\begin{align}\tag{1} \logit(\pi_i)&= \alpha_0 + \varepsilon_i\\ \logit(q_i) &= (\beta_0 + b_{0i}) + (\beta_1 + b_{1i})\logit(p_i), \end{align}$$ where (Œ±0,Œ≤0,Œ≤1)(\alpha_0, \beta_0, \beta_1) are fixed effects, Œµi‚àºN(0,œÉœÄ2)\varepsilon_i\sim N(0, \sigma_\pi^2), $b_i=(b_{0i}, b_{1i})^{\rm T}\sim N(0, \Sigma_b)$, and Œµi‚ä•bi\varepsilon_i\perp b_i. In particular, model (1) maximally allows for study-to-study variations in the prevalence and in the (generally negative) correlation between sensitivity and specificity.

Let ùíû\mathcal C denote the set of indices where complete data are observed. Thus for each i‚ààùíûii\in\mathcal C_i, we have complete estimates of œÄÃÇ\hat\pi, pÃÇi\hat p_i, and qÃÇi\hat q_i. Using them as pseudo-observations in (1), we can estimate the parameters by $\hat\alpha=\mbox{mean}\{\logit(\hat\pi_i): i\in\mathcal C\}$, $\hat\sigma_\pi^2=\mbox{var}\{\logit(\hat\pi_i): i\in\mathcal C\}$, Œ≤ÃÇ=\hat\beta= least-squares estimate of $\logit(\hat q_i) \mbox{ vs }\logit(\hat p_i)$ (i‚ààùíû)(i\in\mathcal C). Finally, Œ£b\Sigma_b can be estimated by Œ£ÃÇb=|ùíû|varÃÇ(Œ≤ÃÇ)\hat\Sigma_b=|\mathcal C|\hat{\mbox{var}}(\hat\beta), where |ùíû||\mathcal C| is the number of studies in ùíû\mathcal C and varÃÇ(Œ≤ÃÇ)\hat{\mbox{var}}(\hat\beta) is the estimated variance matrix of Œ≤ÃÇ\hat\beta under standard least squares.

Imputation process

For any $i\in\overline{\mathcal C}=\{i=1,\ldots, m: \FNi \mbox{ and } \TNi \mbox{ are missing}\}$, we only know NiN_i and pÃÇi\hat p_i, and will have to impute $\FNi$ and $\TNi$. We do so multiple times by drawing random effects from model (1), in order to account for the certainty in the missing values.

At the jjth imputation, for each i‚ààùíû¬Øi\in\overline{\mathcal C}:

  • Draw Œµi(j)‚àºN(0,œÉÃÇœÄ2)\varepsilon_i^{(j)}\sim N(0, \hat\sigma_\pi^2); bi(j)‚àºN(0,Œ£ÃÇb)b_i^{(j)}\sim N(0,\hat\Sigma_b);
  • Compute œÄÃÇi(j)\hat\pi_i^{(j)} and qÃÇi(j)\hat q_i^{(j)} by inserting Œ±ÃÇ0\hat\alpha_0, Œµi(j)\varepsilon_i^{(j)}, Œ≤ÃÇ\hat\beta, and bi(j)b_i^{(j)} in model (1);
  • Impute the missing values by N‚Äæi(j)=Ni(1‚àíœÄÃÇi(j))/œÄÃÇi(j)\bar N_i^{(j)}= N_i(1-\hat\pi_i^{(j)})/\hat\pi_i^{(j)}, $\FNi^{(j)} = \bar N_i^{(j)}(1-\hat q_i^{(j)})$, and $\TNi^{(j)} = \bar N_i^{(j)}\hat q_i^{(j)}$.

We thus obtain a completed dataset $$ \mathcal D^{(j)}= \{(\TPi, \FNi, \FPi^{(j)}, \TNi^{(j)}): i=1,\ldots, m\}, $$ where we define $\FPi^{(j)}=\FPi$ and $\TNi^{(j)}=\TNi$ for i‚ààùíûi\in\mathcal C. Given ùíü(j)\mathcal D^{(j)}, we can use standard software for meta-analysis to obtain a summary measure of diagnostic accuracy, say, the summary AUC, denoted by $\hat{\rm AUC}^{(j)}$. We may also obtain its variance $\hat{\rm var}(\hat{\rm AUC}^{(j)})$.

Repeat the above for j=1,‚Ä¶,Jj =1,\ldots, J (e.g., J=500J=500). Then compute the multiply imputed AUC by $$ \hat{\rm AUC}=J^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^J\hat{\rm AUC}^{(j)}, $$ and its variance by $$ \hat{\rm var}(\hat{\rm AUC}) = \underbrace{J^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^J(\hat{\rm AUC}^{(j)} -\hat{\rm AUC})^2}_{\rm between-imputation} + \underbrace{J^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^J\hat{\rm var}(\hat{\rm AUC}^{(j)})}_{\rm within-imputation}. $$ The above computations can be done on the logit scale of the AUC to improve their accuracy of approximation.

References

Sousa-Pinto, Philipp Doebler with contributions from Bernardo. 2022. ‚ÄúMada: Meta-Analysis of Diagnostic Accuracy.‚Äù https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=mada.
